Literature Review: The economics of crop residue management is a critical issue that affects not only the environment but also the livelihoods of smallholder farmers. The unsustainable practice of burning crop residues, particularly in Asian countries, has severe consequences on air quality, human health, and soil nutrient recycling. This review aims to examine the economic rationale for unsustainable residue management and identify the key factors that determine the sustainability of residue utilization. We will discuss the economic factors that influence residue management, including local demand, technology adoption, and market and policy instruments. Our analysis will also focus on the intervention strategies that can ensure sustainable residue management, particularly those that rely on public awareness of the private and societal costs of open residue burning.
